page.title: 07THE WHITE CLIFFS
page.content:
These are one of Dover's most famous features.The cliffs were built up between seventy and one hundred million years ago, during the upper Cretaceous period. They consist of porous sedimentary rocks, which are easily eroded by the sea. Many fossils can still be found in the cliff rock.
The cliffs are three hundred and seventy five feet high, and fall away steeply into the Straits of Dover. They are continued in France by Camp Blanc Nez - near to Boulogne.
They are in a good strategic position overlooking the channel, and this is why Dover castle and the Roman Pharos were built there.
